messageBody:
Hi Felix,

This is an interesting question, and I don't think it's been brought up here
before.

In my experience, this is a bit hard to quantify, but it's probably fair to
say that while the cost appears a bit on the high side initially (especially
if the developers on your team are not used to writing tests and that there
is no existing testing infrastructure), it tends to decrease over time as
programmers become more experienced in writing tests, reuse or create test
base classes and tend to write solid tests in their first iteration.

Although it's obviously hard to prove or disprove, I would probably say that
at the very beginning, it's not rare to spend as much time writing a test as
it is to implement the corresponding feature. That first test is always
very expensive, especially if it's an area of your product that has no tests
at all. It all gets better after that.

Hope it helps, and looking forward to other people's answers.

--
Cédric
http://testng.org


On 2/16/07, felix3142 <f.noz@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
>
> we're going to establish unit-testing (basically for web applications)
> in our company. Because we don't want to change the whole programming
> paradigm to XP we rather want to use a test-last method in the
> beginning and then watch out for further steps.
> I'm now in the process of investigating the basic requirements and
> conditions.
> One question that occured is if it's possible to quantify the amount
> of extra time you need when using unit testing compared to the
> non-testing approach. I solely refer to the writing of unit tests.
> Later saving of time (by better code) shouldn't be considered. So
> what's your experience? Can anybody do a statement about time
> consumption of writing unit tests?
>
> Regards
> Felix
